qas.question: In addition to Carboniferous, what other insect order is inclusive of extant groups, stem groups and Paleozoic groups?
To what measurement, in cm, did the wingspans of giant dragonfly-like forms reach?
Higher levels of what substance possibly contributed to the phenomenon of gigantism?
How many million years ago is the Permian period believed to have begun?
The most significant mass extinction of insect groups is commonly ascribed to what period?
Late Caboniferous and Early Permain are what kind of orders?
The insect orders include both of what?
The insect orders include a number of what kind of groups?
What kind of giant insect form had wingspans?
How wide were the wingspans of the dragonfly-like forms?

context: Late Carboniferous and <a0_0>Early Permian<a0_0/> <a5_0>insect orders<a5_0/> include both <a6_0>extant groups<a6_0/>, their stem groups, and a number of <a7_0>Paleozoic groups<a7_0/>, now extinct. During this era, some giant <a8_0>dragonfly-like forms<a8_0/> reached wingspans of <a1_0><a9_0>55 to 70<a1_0/> cm<a9_0/> (22 to 28 in), making them far larger than any living insect. This gigantism may have been due to higher atmospheric <a2_0>oxygen<a2_0/> levels that allowed increased respiratory efficiency relative to today. The lack of flying vertebrates could have been another factor. Most extinct orders of insects developed during the Permian period that began around <a3_0>270<a3_0/> million years ago. Many of the early groups became extinct during the <a4_0>Permian-Triassic<a4_0/> extinction event, the largest mass extinction in the history of the Earth, around 252 million years ago.
